title: Lindsay Clancy appears in court for first in-person hearing since allegedly killing her children
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Lindsay Clancy appeared in court for the first time in-person since allegedly killing her three children in 2023.
Clancy faces charges for the murders of her children and is pursuing an insanity defense, focusing on mental illness.
The July murder trial may be split into phases; a decision on this request will be made on March 2.

title: Cape Cod adopts transfer fee on home sales over $1 million
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Barnstable County Assembly approved a transfer fee on home sales over $1 million to address Cape Cod's housing crisis.
The proposed fee could raise up to $60 million annually, with towns deciding on implementation through local votes.
90% of the funds will go to towns for housing initiatives, while 10% supports a regional year-round housing trust.

title: Peabody police warn about ‘Northshore Mall takeover’
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Peabody police are on alert for a planned 'Northshore Mall takeover' at 3 p.m. Friday to ensure public safety.
Events called 'takeovers' often involve large crowds and can include illegal activities like car burnouts and drag racing.
Governor Maura Healey issued a $14 million grant to prevent such incidents after previous meetups led to violence.

title: 7 members of ‘Harvard Street Gang’ face drug and firearms charges, authorities say
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Seven members of the Brockton-based Harvard Street Gang face federal drug and firearms charges following a major investigation.
Authorities seized 25 firearms, multiple kilograms of drugs, and tens of thousands in cash in Eastern Massachusetts.
Court records show the investigation, ongoing since 2019, linked the gang to drug trafficking and violent crimes.

title: Al Horford says his decision to leave Celtics was ‘deeper than just the basketball’
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Al Horford left the Celtics for the Warriors citing reasons beyond basketball, hinting at non-basketball issues.
The Celtics aimed to reduce salary under the luxury tax, while Horford sought a new opportunity.
Horford praised Celtics coach Joe Mazzulla's program and left open the possibility of retiring with the Celtics.

title: Readers agree: Build a new Madison Park to benefit Boston’s youth
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Boston.com readers support building a new vocational high school at the P-3 parcel in Roxbury.
The Madison Park Technical Vocational High School is seen as offering valuable career paths without requiring college.
Readers emphasize the need for improved school infrastructure and training in trades for Boston's youth.

title: Planned Parenthood rolls out vasectomies at Mass. health centers
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Planned Parenthood League of Massachusetts now offers vasectomies at its Worcester health center, with consultations available at four locations.
The demand for permanent contraception, including vasectomies, has increased significantly since federal abortion protections were overturned in 2022.
On November 6, 2024, Planned Parenthood affiliates reported a 1,200% surge in vasectomy bookings following Trump's presidential reelection.

title: Body of Eastham man who fell through ice located after days of searching
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Gerard 'Jerry' Boucher's body was found Feb. 20 after he fell through the ice at First Encounter Beach on Feb. 14.
Rescue teams searched the marshy area northeast of Bee's River parking lot where Jerry Boucher was eventually located.
Kit Boucher, Jerry's wife, also fell through the ice and was found deceased shortly after the incident occurred.

title: MSP trooper dragged by vehicle during East Boston stop
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Trooper dragged 10-20 feet by car in East Boston during early morning stop; suspect fled, trooper sustained nonlife-threatening injuries.
Suspect, Binit Bikram Shah, 27, arrested in New Hampshire; showed signs of impairment and was charged with multiple offenses.
Charges include assault and battery with a dangerous weapon, DUI, driving with a suspended license, and drug possession.

title: Here’s why readers support voter ID laws, even as some take issue with SAVE America Act
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: The SAVE America Act, if passed, will require voters to show proof of citizenship and photo ID for federal elections.
Massachusetts congresspeople criticize the act, citing potential disenfranchisement and lack of widespread voter fraud.
A Pew poll found 83% of respondents support voter ID; some Boston.com readers favor ID but criticize the SAVE Act's implications.
